posts.cooked:
is this U-channel considered sharp? Will it pass the robot inspection? do you have any ideas on how to do an end cap for this? Is there any 3D CAD file that you can share or online where I can buy it? I u-channel 888×832 171 KB appreciate any help you can provide.

u-channel 888×832 171 KB

u-channel 888×832 171 KB

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
Depends on your inspector. If you are concerned, probably best to play it safe and fix the issue.

Get a deburing to to clean it up if you are concerned: Amazon.com

Edit: spelling is hard.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.name: Owen Murtha
posts.cooked: If you feel like you could cut or scrape yourself on it, it’s probably too sharp. Some inspectors may have a problem with it, and some might not. Either way, I would probably just round off those corners with a file to be safe.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
Yes as an RI, I would call that sharp. It is also easy to fix. With a file break the 90 degree corner. Slightly rounded or 1/8ish fillet works. Making an end cap would be nice but not in my interpretation a rule requirement.

On our robots we take an angle grinder with a flappy wheel and knock off these sort of sharp edges in  about a minute. (If you are at an event be sure to use and angle sander and not an angle grinder )

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: A freshman with a file will also work sufficiently.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: But the freshman powered sander it more fun.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
AdamF:

freshman with a file

That depends on the freshman.  If your team is fortunate enough to have a grey haired metal shop teacher on board, the designated freshman can be taught how to use a file correctly.  If no grey hair is available, you might have some upper class students with the right experience to provide similar training.

Untrained filers can do more harm than good, or spend way to much time, or both.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
Richard_Wallace:

If your team is fortunate enough to have a grey haired metal shop

The problem with greyed haired shop teachers is they tend to think that learning to file properly is a right of passage bordering on hazing. Having said that, it drives me nuts to watch people back dragging a file.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked:
Lexeo:

Get a debuting to to clean it up if you are concerned:

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Nothing like watching someone back dragging a dirty file flat to the cut, with no pressure applied…

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
For students reading this who don’t have a local shop teacher:

Metal files are relatively inexpensive and effective tools for reshaping and smoothing metal and hard plastics, offering the potential for high precision and many years of trouble-free use. Be sure to select the right kind of file for the...

(I’m sure there’s some good YouTube tutorials videos out there as well)

link_counts.title: How to File Metal: 12 Steps (with Pictures) - wikiHow

posts.cooked: What we do is if you can rub a baby on it then it’s okay

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: Before YP we used to use a baby’s but for comparison.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked:
The standard I like to use when instructing my students is as follows.

If you don’t feel safe rubbing it against your face, not hard, but with some actual pressure, then you have not deburred your part fully.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: You will poke your eye out

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
No, you’re NOT getting a Red Ryder!

If you can use it to shave with, you didn’t deburr it right.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: I am always telling my students that holding it in you hand is bad and any noise you are making is also bad. Vibration in your hand or making sound is literally you wasting energy, that is energy that is not CUTTING the part. Clamp the part or hold it against something that is actually solid!

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: I said IF they don’t FEEL safe, not to actually do it!

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked:
If you wouldn’t want people to rub their fingers against it then yes it’s sharp.

I would either file it down OR you could put electrical tape over it if your in a time crunch

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked: If we are in a time crunch we usually put grey gaffers tape over the corners of the metal to soften the edges.
